chapter.title: Troubleshooting &cephadm;
chapter.para: As &cephadm; deploys daemons as containers, troubleshooting daemons is slightly different. Here are a few tools and commands to help investigating issues.

sect1.title: Pausing or disabling &cephadm;
sect1.para: If something goes wrong and &cephadm; is behaving in a way you do not like, you can pause most background activity by executing the following:
This will stop any changes, but &cephadm; will still periodically check hosts to refresh its inventory of daemons and devices. You can disable &cephadm; completely with:
sect1.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph orch set backend '' &prompt.cephuser;ceph mgr module disable cephadm
sect1.para: This disables all of the ceph orch ... CLI commands but the previously deployed daemon containers will continue to exist and start as they did before.

sect1.title: Accessing &ceph; daemon logs
sect1.para: &productname; &productnumber; supports &ceph; logging via systemd-journald. To access the logs of &ceph; daemons in &productname; &productnumber;, follow the instructions below.

step.para: Use the ceph orch ps command (or ceph orch ps node_name or ceph orch ps --daemon-type daemon_type) to find the &cephadm; name of the daemon where the host is running.
For example, if you want to view the logs for &prometheus;, run the following command to find the name of the daemon:
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph orch ps --daemon-type prometheus NAME HOST STATUS REFRESHED AGE VERSION IMAGE NAME IMAGE ID CONTAINER ID prometheus.master master running (65m) 7m ago 2h 2.18.0 registry.suse.com/caasp/v4.5/prometheus-server:2.18.0 e77db6e75e78 7b11062150ab
step.para: In this example, prometheus.master is the name and the host is master.

sect1.title: Collecting systemd status
sect1.para: To print the state of a systemd unit, run:
sect1.screen: systemctl status "ceph-$(cephadm shell ceph fsid)@service name.service";
sect1.para: To fetch all state of all daemons of a given host, run:
sect1.screen: fsid="$(cephadm shell ceph fsid)" for name in $(cephadm ls | jq -r '.[].name') ; do systemctl status "ceph-$fsid@$name.service" > $name; done

sect2.title: Assessing SSH errors
sect2.para: If you receive the following error:
sect2.screen: xxxxxx.gateway_bootstrap.HostNotFound: -F /tmp/cephadm-conf-kbqvkrkw root@10.10.1.2 raise OrchestratorError('Failed to connect to %s (%s). Check that the host is reachable and accepts connections using the cephadm SSH key' % (host, addr)) from orchestrator._interface.OrchestratorError: Failed to connect to 10.10.1.2 (10.10.1.2). Check that the host is reachable and accepts connections using the cephadm SSH key
sect2.para: You can verify the issue by trialing a few different options.

listitem.para: Ensure &cephadm; has an SSH identity key:
listitem.screen: &prompt.smaster;cephadm shell -- ceph config-key get mgr/cephadm/ssh_identity_key > key INFO:cephadm:Inferring fsid f8edc08a-7f17-11ea-8707-000c2915dd98 INFO:cephadm:Using recent ceph image docker.io/ceph/ceph:v15 obtained 'mgr/cephadm/ssh_identity_key' &prompt.smaster;chmod 0600 key
listitem.para: If this fails, &cephadm; does not have a key. Fix this by running the following command:
listitem.screen: &prompt.smaster;cat key | cephadm shell -- ceph cephadm set-ssk-key -i -

sect2.title: Verifying public key is in authorized_keys
sect2.para: To verify that the public key is in the authorized_keys file, run the following commands:
sect2.screen: &prompt.smaster;cephadm shell -- ceph config-key get mgr/cephadm/ssh_identity_pub > key.pub &prompt.smaster;grep "`cat key.pub`" /root/.ssh/authorized_keys

sect1.title: Deploying a &mgr; manually
sect1.para: Use the following steps to deploy a new &mgr; on a host.

step.para: Disable the &cephadm; scheduler, in order to prevent &cephadm; from removing the new &mgr;:

step.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph auth create DAEMON_NAME mon "profile mgr" osd "allow *" mds "allow *"
step.para: If you already have an auth entry, you can get the entry with the following command:
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph auth get DAEMON_NAME mon "profile mgr" osd "allow *" mds "allow *"

sect1.title: Distributing a program temporary fix (PTF)
sect1.para: Occasionally, in order to fix a given issue, &suse; will provide a set of packages known as a Program Temporary Fix (PTF). Such a PTF is fully supported by &suse; until the Maintenance Update (MU) containing a permanent fix has been released via the regular update repositories. Customers running PTF fixes will be notified through the related Service Request when a permanent patch for a PTF has been released.
With &cephadm;, deploying the PTF is already possible by redeploying a specific daemon with a specific container_image.

sect1.title: Failure When Adding Hosts with &cephadm;
sect1.para: When &cephadm; fails to add a new cluster host—no matter whether by means of &cephsalt; (see ) or manually using the ceph orch host add command—you can diagnose the reason for failure. The failure message has the following pattern:
For example:
sect1.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph orch host add node5.example.com Failed to connect to node5 (node5.example.com).
sect1.para: If the message includes a fully qualified domain name (FQDN, node5.example com in our example) as the HOSTNAME, try adding the host using its FQDN:
If either of the previous two commands succeed, &cephsalt; is probably causing the problem. Otherwise, try adding the host using its short host name and IP address:
If this succeeds, the cluster does not have proper name resolution. Refer to for more details.

sect1.title: Disabling automatic deployment of daemons
sect1.para: By default, &ceph; daemons are automatically deployed to new hosts after you add these hosts to the placement specification and apply it (refer to for more details).
sect1.screen:
cat mgr.yaml service_type: mgr unmanaged: true placement: label: mgr [...]
&prompt.cephuser;ceph orch apply -i mgr.yaml
